revision.text:
{{Use British English|date=February 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2013}} {{Infobox comedian | image = Sarah Millican 2010.jpg | caption = Millican in 2010 | image_size = | name = Sarah Millican | nationality = British | birth_name = Sarah Jane King | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1975|5|29|df=y}} | birth_place = [[South Shields]], [[Tyne and Wear]], England | medium = Stand-up, television, radio | genre = [[Observational comedy]] | subject = [[Interpersonal relationship|Relationship]]s, [[body image]], television | active = 2004–present | influences = | domesticpartner = | spouse = {{marriage|Andrew Millican|5 November 1997|2004|end=divorced}}
{{marriage|[[Gary Delaney]]|December 2013}} | website = [https://www.sarahmillican.co.uk/ www.sarahmillican.co.uk] }} '''Sarah Jane Millican''' ({{nee}} '''King''';Who Do You Think You Are?, BBC TV, broadcast 11 September 2013 born 29 May 1975){{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2013/may/05/sarah-millican-comedy | location=London | work=The Guardian | first=Vanessa | last=Thorpe | title=How Sarah Millican struck comedy gold | date=5 May 2013 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161219170851/https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2013/may/05/sarah-millican-comedy | archivedate=19 December 2016 | df=dmy-all }} is an English comedian. Millican won the [[if.comedy award]] for Best Newcomer at the [[2008 Edinburgh Festival Fringe]].{{cite news |url=http://www.metro.co.uk/metrolife/article.html?Sarah_Millican_isnt_resting_on_her_laurels&in_article_id=354075&in_page_id=275 |work=Metro |title=Sarah Millican isn't resting on her laurels |author=Mickey Noonan |date=13 October 2008 |accessdate=13 May 2009}} In February 2013 she was listed as one of the 100 most powerful women in the United Kingdom by Radio 4's ''Woman's Hour'', and in the same year married fellow comedian [[Gary Delaney]]. Her first book, ''How to Be Champion'', was released in 2017, and Millican has performed on various tours mainly throughout the [[United Kingdom]] over the years. ==Life and career== ===Early life=== Millican was born and brought up in [[South Shields]], England, the daughter of Valerie Prince and Philip D. King, who was a mining electrician. She attended Mortimer Comprehensive School, later to become [[Mortimer Community College]],{{cite web|title=Sarah Millican profile|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/profiles/5f6FJvJZxpRQrHzTT7K92Cv/sarah-millican|website=BBC Radio 4|accessdate=31 December 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160119145824/http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/profiles/5f6FJvJZxpRQrHzTT7K92Cv/sarah-millican|archivedate=19 January 2016|df=dmy-all}} and then worked as a civil servant at a [[job centre]] until the age of 29.[https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/comedy/features/funny-girl-sarah-millican-on-comedy-money-and-marriage-7468496.html Funny Girl: Sarah Millican in The Independent] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140307015623/http://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/comedy/features/funny-girl-sarah-millican-on-comedy-money-and-marriage-7468496.html |date=7 March 2014 }} Retrieved 27 June 2015 She was married on 5 November 1997''[[8 Out of 10 Cats]]'', 4 November 2014 but divorced in 2004 and moved back in with her parents for two and a half years. ===2005–2009: Career beginnings and touring=== Millican's debut [[Edinburgh Festival Fringe]] show ''Sarah Millican's Not Nice'', inspired by her divorce, won the [[if.comedy award]] for Best Newcomer in 2008.{{cite web |author=Tim Arthur |work=Time Out |title=Sarah Millican: interview |url=https://www.timeout.com/london/comedy/features/6431/Sarah_Millican-interview.html |date=10 December 2008 |accessdate=13 May 2009 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090617051545/http://www.timeout.com/london/comedy/features/6431/Sarah_Millican-interview.html |archivedate=17 June 2009 |df=dmy-all }} In spring 2009 she began previewing her second Edinburgh show, attracting enthusiastic reviews for her material on the battle of the sexes.{{cite news|title=What you thought of Liverpool's comedy festival: Sarah Millican, Justin Moorhouse and Drink Up Stand Up |date=6 May 2009 |author=David Durkin and Sarah Newman |url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/liverpool-entertainment/echo-reviews/2009/05/06/what-you-thought-of-liverpool-s-comedy-festival-sarah-millican-justin-moorhouse-and-drink-up-stand-up-92534-23555517/ |work=Liverpool Echo |accessdate=13 May 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120319195842/http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/liverpool-entertainment/echo-reviews/2009/05/06/what-you-thought-of-liverpool-s-comedy-festival-sarah-millican-justin-moorhouse-and-drink-up-stand-up-92534-23555517/ |archivedate=19 March 2012 }}{{cite web |url=http://thelatest.co.uk/7/review-of-the-week-sarah-millican-%E2%80%93-typical-woman |title=Review of the week: Sarah Millican – Typical Woman |work=Latest 7 |author=Victoria Nangle |date=21 July 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110728154517/http://thelatest.co.uk/7/review-of-the-week-sarah-millican-%E2%80%93-typical-woman |archivedate=28 July 2011 |df=dmy-all }} Many reviewers commented on her 'blue' material.{{cite news |url=http://www.journallive.co.uk/culture-newcastle/arts-news/2009/08/01/sarah-millican-typical-woman-live-theatre-61634-24289187/ |title=Sarah Millican: Typical Woman, Live Theatre |author=Sam Wonfor |work=The Journal |date=1 August 2009 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120223054746/http://www.journallive.co.uk/culture-newcastle/arts-news/2009/08/01/sarah-millican-typical-woman-live-theatre-61634-24289187/ |archivedate=23 February 2012 |df=dmy-all }} Her third show, ''Chatterbox'', was hosted by the Stand Comedy Club{{cite podcast |url=http://www.comedy.co.uk/podcasts/richard_herring_edinburgh/2013_13_sarah_millican_geoff_norcott/ |title=Richard Herring's Edinburgh Fringe Podcast |host=Richard Herring |date=14 August 2013 |accessdate=16 August 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150107082640/http://www.comedy.co.uk/podcasts/richard_herring_edinburgh/2013_13_sarah_millican_geoff_norcott/ |archivedate=7 January 2015 |df=dmy-all }} during Fringe 2010.{{cite news |title=Sarah Millican leads the comedy pack home |url=http://www.journallive.co.uk/culture-newcastle/arts-news/2010/08/11/sarah-leads-the-comedy-pack-home-61634-27037198/ |first=Sam |last=Wonfor |date=11 August 2010 |work=The Journal |accessdate=13 August 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120203183318/http://www.journallive.co.uk/culture-newcastle/arts-news/2010/08/11/sarah-leads-the-comedy-pack-home-61634-27037198/ |archivedate=3 February 2012 |df=dmy-all }} The show was nominated for the main [[Edinburgh Comedy Award]], losing to [[Russell Kane]].{{cite web |title=Two women make the shortlist |url=http://www.chortle.co.uk/news/2010/08/25/11607/two_women_make_the_shortlist |date=25 August 2010 |work=Chortle |accessdate=25 August 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100828103104/http://www.chortle.co.uk/news/2010/08/25/11607/two_women_make_the_shortlist |archivedate=28 August 2010 |df=dmy-all }} ===2009–present: mainstream success and DVDs, TV and radio shows=== Millican has appeared as a panellist on ''[[8 out of 10 Cats]]'', ''[[Have I Got News For You]]'', ''[[Mock the Week]]'', ''[[You Have Been Watching]]'', ''[[Would I Lie to You? (TV series)|Would I Lie to You?]]'', ''[[QI]]'' and ''[[Never Mind the Buzzcocks]]'', and as a performer at ''[[The Secret Policeman's Ball 2008]]'' and on ''[[4 Stands Up]]''. She was featured in the Manchester edition of ''[[Michael McIntyre's Comedy Roadshow]]'', which was broadcast in June 2009,{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/pressreleases/stories/2009/04_april/23/mcintyre.shtml |title=New comedy tops bill on BBC One this summer with Michael McIntyre's Comedy Roadshow |date=23 April 2009 |work=BBC |accessdate=14 May 2009 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090426121342/http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/pressreleases/stories/2009/04_april/23/mcintyre.shtml |archivedate=26 April 2009 |df=dmy-all }} made an appearance on the third episode of [[David Mitchell (comedian)|David Mitchell]]'s panel show ''[[The Bubble (UK TV series)|The Bubble]]'' in March 2010,{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/pressreleases/stories/2010/02_february/02/bubble.shtml |title=The Bubble, a brand-new comedy news quiz on BBC Two |work=[[BBC]] |date=2 February 2010 |accessdate=20 February 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100219171524/http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/pressreleases/stories/2010/02_february/02/bubble.shtml |archivedate=19 February 2010 |df=dmy-all }} and has been a guest on six episodes of ''[[Frank Skinner's Opinionated]]''. She provided vocal work to the BBC's [[natural history]] footage for ''[[Walk on the Wild Side (TV series)|Walk on the Wild Side]]'', alongside fellow comics [[Rhod Gilbert]], [[Jon Richardson (comedian)|Jon Richardson]], [[Isy Suttie]] and [[Gavin Webster]].{{cite news |url=http://thescotsman.scotsman.com/features/Interview-Sarah-Millican39s-standup-is.5509942.jp |title=Interview: Sarah Millican's stand-up is in the worst possible taste |work=The Scotsman |date=1 August 2009 |accessdate=8 August 2009}} She appeared on ''[[Live at the Apollo (TV series)|Live at the Apollo]]'' on 11 December 2009, and headlined ''[[Michael McIntyre's Comedy Roadshow]]'', recorded at the [[Empire Theatre, Sunderland]] on 15 August 2010. Millican also headlined the fourth episode of ''[[Dave's One Night Stand]]''.{{cite web |url=http://www.comedy.co.uk/guide/tv/one_night_stand/episodes/1/4/ |title=Episode 1.4 |author=Ian Wolf |publisher=[[British Comedy Guide]] |accessdate=9 October 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120418144528/http://www.comedy.co.uk/guide/tv/one_night_stand/episodes/1/4/ |archivedate=18 April 2012 |df=dmy-all }} Her radio series, ''Sarah Millican's Support Group'', began broadcasting on 18 February 2010 on [[BBC Radio 4]].{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/proginfo/radio/2010/wk7/thu.shtml#thu_sarah |title=R4 Sarah Millican's Support Group |work=BBC Press Office |date=18 February 2010 |accessdate=18 February 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100224213605/http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/proginfo/radio/2010/wk7/thu.shtml#thu_sarah |archivedate=24 February 2010 |df=dmy-all }} The format is that studio audience members are encouraged to share problems with her agony aunt character for her to offer tips "in the same way as the busybody at the end of your street who knows everything and dishes out advice whether you want to hear it or not does". Some problems are scripted, the roles being played by guest actors, while others come from real people in the audience, to allow Sarah to improvise. Audience member problems have included "My boyfriend prefers his Blackberry to me". A pair of "therapists", also played by actors, feature in each week's show and provide scripted and improvised responses to all the "problems".{{cite web |url=http://www.chortle.co.uk/news/2009/11/10/9923/r4_series_for_millican |title=R4 series for Millican |work=Chortle |date=10 November 2009 |accessdate=10 November 2009 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091114065112/http://www.chortle.co.uk/news/2009/11/10/9923/r4_series_for_millican |archivedate=14 November 2009 |df=dmy-all }} A second series debuted on [[BBC Radio 4 Extra]] on 2 May 2011.{{cite web|url=http://www.comedy.co.uk/guide/radio/sarah_millicans_support_group/episodes/2/|title=Sarah Millican's Support Group|publisher=[[British Comedy Guide]]|accessdate=14 June 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121013024949/http://www.comedy.co.uk/guide/radio/sarah_millicans_support_group/episodes/2/|archivedate=13 October 2012|df=dmy-all}} She was a regular co-host of the satirical news show ''[[7 Day Sunday]]'' on [[BBC Radio 5 Live]], along with comedians [[Chris Addison]], [[Andy Zaltzman]] and one different guest each week. The first episode aired in January 2010; she and Addison left the show on 27 February 2011. In December 2011, she voiced three [[Viz (comic)|Viz]] ''Comedy Blaps'' alongside [[Steve Coogan]], [[Simon Greenall]] and [[Gavin Webster]] for Channel 4.{{cite news | url=http://www.skwigly.co.uk/viz-animation-blap-to-basics/ | work=Skwigly | title=Viz Animation – "Blap" to basics | date=12 December 2011 | accessdate=6 January 2012 | last=Henderson | first=Steve | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120114100817/http://www.skwigly.co.uk/viz-animation-blap-to-basics/ | archivedate=14 January 2012 | df=dmy-all }} Also in 2011, Millican became a panellist on the [[ITV Network|ITV]] programme ''Marriage Ref'' and joined the panel on ITV daytime chat show ''[[Loose Women]]'', leaving the series in August. She was also a guest on several other panel and chat shows. A live DVD of her ''Chatterbox'' tour was released in November 2011 by Channel 4.{{cite web|title=Sarah Millican signs DVD deal|url=http://www.chortle.co.uk/news/2010/08/24/11602/sarah_millican_signs_dvd_deal|work=Chortle|date=24 August 2010|accessdate=24 August 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100828110420/http://www.chortle.co.uk/news/2010/08/24/11602/sarah_millican_signs_dvd_deal|archivedate=28 August 2010|df=dmy-all}} The Chatterbox DVD went on to break an all-time record in sales for a female stand-up comedian selling 172,000 copies in just over one month.{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/theatre/comedy/8971413/Sarah-Millican-reflects-on-her-remarkable-DVD-sales-success.html |title=Sarah Millican reflects on her remarkable DVD sales success |work=The Telegraph |date=21 December 2011 |accessdate=16 February 2013 |last=Cavendish |first=Dominic |location=London |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120408032156/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/theatre/comedy/8971413/Sarah-Millican-reflects-on-her-remarkable-DVD-sales-success.html |archivedate=8 April 2012 |df=dmy-all }} Millican's stand-up show, ''[[The Sarah Millican Television Programme]]'', was first broadcast on 8 March 2012 on [[BBC Two]]. In November 2012, she released a follow-up live DVD, ''Thoroughly Modern Millican''. In early January 2013, she appeared for a couple of nights on ''[[The One Show]]''. On 15 January 2013, she began presenting a second series of ''The Sarah Millican Television Programme''. Millican was nominated for 2013 and 2014 BAFTA Entertainment Performance awards for her work in ''The Sarah Millican Television Programme''.{{cite web|title=Television in 2013|url=http://awards.bafta.org/award/2013/television|website=BAFTA|publisher=[[British Academy of Film and Television Arts]]|accessdate=31 December 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6WszoVlVp?url=http://awards.bafta.org/award/2013/television|archivedate=8 March 2015|df=dmy-all}} Millican appeared in a celebrity episode of ''[[Deal or No Deal (UK game show)|Deal or No Deal]]'' broadcast on 29 April 2012, where she won £20,000 for charity. She had £100,000 in her box. Millican also appeared on the [[Comic Relief]] 2015: Face the Funny TV Programme, broadcast on Friday 13 March 2015, Where she was a host for the [[BBC]] [[Comic Relief]] show. In May 2015 it was announced that Millican would be made the eighth "curator" of ''[[The Museum of Curiosity]]'', co-presenting the eighth series of the [[BBC Radio 4]] comedy series.{{cite web|last=Dessau|first=Bruce|authorlink=Bruce Dessau|url=http://www.beyondthejoke.co.uk/content/1677/news-sarah-millican-curates-museum|title=News: Sarah Millican Curates Museum|publisher=Beyond the Joke|date=6 May 2015|accessdate=6 May 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150510160850/http://www.beyondthejoke.co.uk/content/1677/news-sarah-millican-curates-museum|archivedate=10 May 2015|df=dmy-all}} Millican's autobiography, ''How to be Champion'', was published in October 2017.{{cite web|title=Sarah Millican: How to be Champion|url=https://www.orionbooks.co.uk/books/detail.page?isbn=9781409174332|work=Orion Books|accessdate=3 October 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171003231505/https://www.orionbooks.co.uk/books/detail.page?isbn=9781409174332|archivedate=3 October 2017|df=dmy-all}} That month she also announced dates for her 2018 UK tour, "Sarah Millican: Control Enthusiast". ==Personal life== After her husband Andrew Millican left her unexpectedly in 2004,{{cite news | url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/comedy/features/funny-girl-sarah-millican-on-comedy-money-and-marriage-7468496.html | location=London | work=The Independent | first=Gerard | last=Gilbert | title=Funny girl: Sarah Millican on comedy, money and marriage | date=2 March 2012 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140307015623/http://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/comedy/features/funny-girl-sarah-millican-on-comedy-money-and-marriage-7468496.html | archivedate=7 March 2014 | df=dmy-all }} Millican found solace in attending writing workshops in local theatres, such as at [[Newcastle upon Tyne|Newcastle's]] [[Live Theatre]] and the [[The Customs House, South Shields|Customs House]] in [[South Shields]]. Jokes about her failed marriage initially formed the vast majority of Millican's comedy material. {{cite news |title=Sarah Millican preview |work=Scotland on Sunday |author= Chitra Ramaswamy |date=10 August 2008 |url=http://scotlandonsunday.scotsman.com/edinburghfestivalfringe/Sarah-Millican-preview-.4372939.jp |accessdate=13 May 2009}} She began a relationship with fellow stand-up comic [[Gary Delaney]] in 2006.[http://www.express.co.uk/celebrity-news/451961/Sarah-Millican-marries-fellow-comedian-Gary-Delaney-in-secret-ceremony Sarah Millican marries Gary Delaney] The couple moved in together in 2013 and married in December 2013.{{cite web|last1=Strang|first1=Fay|title=Sarah Millican has married fellow comedian Gary Delaney in secret festive ceremony|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-2533419/Sarah-Millican-married-fellow-comedian-Gary-Delany-secret-festive-ceremony.html|website=Daily Mail|accessdate=31 December 2016|date=3 January 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160920061028/http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-2533419/Sarah-Millican-married-fellow-comedian-Gary-Delany-secret-festive-ceremony.html|archivedate=20 September 2016|df=dmy-all}} The couple own two cats and one dog, and live in [[Manchester]]. ==Stand-up DVDs== *''Chatterbox Live'' (21 November 2011) *''Thoroughly Modern Millican Live'' (12 November 2012) *''Home Bird Live'' (17 November 2014) *''Outsider Live'' (21 November 2016) ==Bibliography== *''How to be Champion'' (Trapeze, 2017) {{ISBN|9781409174301}} ==Awards and nominations== * [[So You Think You're Funny?]] (2nd place) 2005 * [[BBC New Comedy Awards]] (finalist) 2005 * [[Funny Women]] (runner-up) 2005 * Amused Moose (winner) * [[Chortle Awards]] (Best Newcomer nomination) 2006 * North West Comedy Awards (Best Breakthrough Act) 2007{{cite web |url=http://www.manchesterconfidential.com/index.asp?Sessionx=IpqiNwY6IWXrIHqiNwF6IHqi|archive-url=https://archive.is/20070810055349/http://www.manchesterconfidential.com/index.asp?Sessionx=IpqiNwY6IWXrIHqiNwF6IHqi|dead-url=yes|archive-date=10 August 2007|title=The Northwest Comedy Awards |date=27 January 2007 |work=Manchester Confidential |accessdate=16 May 2009}} * [[if.comedy award]] (Best Newcomer) 2008 *[[Edinburgh Comedy Award]] 2010 (Best show nomination) *[[British Comedy Awards#2011|British Comedy Award People’s Choice Award for the King or Queen of Comedy 2011]] In February 2013 Millican was assessed as one of the 100 most powerful women in the United Kingdom by ''[[Woman's Hour]]'' on [[BBC Radio 4]].{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b007qlvb/features/power-list-100 |title=The Power List 2013 |work=BBC Radio 4 |publisher=BBC |date= |accessdate=16 February 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130215063524/http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b007qlvb/features/power-list-100 |archivedate=15 February 2013 |df=dmy-all }} ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== *{{Official website|http://www.sarahmillican.co.uk}} *[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/7579520.stm BBC story about 2008 Perrier Award] *[http://www.chortle.co.uk/comics/s/484/sarah_millican Biography from Chortle.co.uk] *[http://www.bbc.co.uk/cultureshow/videos/2008/08/edinb_s5_e3_millican/index.shtml BBC – The Culture Show] Interview with Lauren Laverne *{{IMDb name|3155853}} {{s-start}} {{succession box|title=[[if.comedy award]] for Best Newcomer|before=[[Tom Basden]]|after=[[Jonny Sweet]]|years=2008}} {{s-end}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Millican, Sarah}} [[Category:Living people]] radio personalities]] [[Category:English stand-up comedians]] [[Category:English women comedians]] [[Category:People from South Shields]] [[Category:Television personalities from Tyne and Wear]]
